div.p: THE CITY BRIDE: OR, The Merry Cuckold.
A COMEDY, Acted at the New Theatre, in Little Lincolns Inn-Fields.
LONDON: Printed for A. Roper and E. Wilkinson at the Black-Boy, and R. Clavel at the Peacock, in Fleet-street. 1606.

div.head: TO THE HONOURABLE Sir John Walter, Bar.
div.p: UNder the present License of the Press, and Freedom of Religion, Two very fair Establish'd English Liberties; methinks I have the Umbrage even of a Law on my side, to Authorize my Presumption, in paying this publick Devotion, to so Worthy a Patron; and fixing so fair a Name, in the Frontispiece of so poor a Trifle.

You must pardon me, Sir, if I lay hold of all occasions, and every Argument to warrant my Ambition: Besides, I have a stronger Charter than Poetick Priviledge, 'tis my Gratitude that dictates to my Pen; You have already vouchsaf'd to Honour me with your Smiles, (and where such Goodness descends, 'tis natural for our Pride to aspire) whil'st warm'd and animated by that only Encouragement, I am embolden'd to make you this Dedication; insomuch that my present Devoirs have more of the Thanksgiving, than the Prayer; a Duteous Acknowledgment for Blessings already received. And here I must avow to the World, That in Addressing to a person Enrich'd with so many Generous Accomplishments, I▪ set not out a Discoverer, a Columbus to any unknown Golden Coast: No, Sir, Your
past Favours have swell'd my Sails, whil'st I am carried by a fair Levant to an open free Port, and a Hospitable Shoar.

That Sweetness of Temper runs through all Your Conversation, so free from any Allay of Pride, (that too common Taint of Prosperity,) that You have all the Sweets of the Rose, without the prickles. Your Goodness so Frank, and so diffusive, and the Access to it so Easie, that those who have the more particular happiness of Your nearest Intimacay, and Friendship, find those Charms in Your Conversation, that they are scarce (pardon the seeming Contradiction,) to be enjoy'd: For the more they are possest, the more they are desir'd.

HONOUR, and GALLANTRY are not only Born, but bred up with You. You Challenge not only all the Advantages of a Fair and Generous Birth, but You have all the Improvements of a Generous and Sprightly Genius too, with so forward, so hopeful, and so growing a Merit (that ample Addition to your Hereditary Desert) that the Stem is a Grace to the Root.

If Providence does ever Study for her Fair Creations, she Thinks when she makes a Compleat Gentleman. And Fortune in the Donations of her Golden Favours upon You, has not Showr'd them at Random; she found that WORTH, that challeng'd her Smiles, and her Graces are not her Gift, but her Reward.

But to all Your other Felicities there's the chief one yet wanting, to compleat the Summ; the Charms of LOVE, that double Heaven of Joy, where You must give Blessings when You receive them. And here I must beg your leave, to wish You that truly fair and Virtuous Choice, That like the Famous Youth of Troy, You may have Rival Beauties all waiting when your kind Hand shall give the Prize, and bestow the Ball of Gold. And truly, the Generous and the Brave shou'd ever make Love,
their nearest Care. For indeed, Love is the only Foundation of Immortality. For though Noble Virtues, a Sweet Fame, and Fragrant Memory may keep a fair Name alive; yet to make Your self live for Ever, You only want a Lovely Feminine Partner, to draw Living Copies from so Excellent an Original.

But I must not dwell too long upon this Subject, For as Dedications are by Custom, only the Panegyricks upon the Patron's Virtues, possibly to so much Modesty, (one of your most shining Perfections,) I may make but ungrateful Musick on that Theme. Yet why shou'd WORTH and HONOUR any more Blush to hear their own just Praises, then the Hero, or Monarch his Triumph, or Coronation Song. The Theme on this side may be as Copious, and as inspiring as that; Desert and Applause are not confin'd only to Palaces and Thrones; the Chapplet sometimes may Sparkle, as well as the Diadem. 'Tis true the Encomiums of Extraordinary Desert; are what my poorest of Quills shou'd not presume to attempt, as being a Province for the Elder Sons of Apollo; and yet when I consider, that the Ayres that are tuned but to an Oaten Pipe, may be as chearfully and heartily Sung, though not so sweetly and loud as to a Silver Trumpet; I have that only Plea for this Boldness, which gives me the Honour of Subscribing my self,

closer.signed: Your most Oblig'd, Most Devoted, And Obedient Servant, Joseph Harris

div.head: PROLOGUE:
div.l: THREE Ways there are, and all accounted fair,
To gain your Favour: Begging, Borrowing, Prayer.
If as a Beggar, I your Alms implore
Methinks your Charity shou'd aid the Poor;
Besides, I never beg'd of you before.
If I address by Prayer, and loud Complaints
I then oblige yee, for I make you Saints;
And sure none here can think it Superstition,
To pray to Saints that are of no Religion!
If Invocation will not do my Work,
A Man may borrow of a Jew or Turk;
Pray lend me Gentlemen your Applause and Praise,
I'll take it for as good as Currant Bays;
And if I ne're repay it, 'tis no more,
Than many of you Sparks have done before:
With this distinction, that you ran indebt
For want of Money, we for want of Wit.
In vain I plead! a Man as soon may get
Mill'd Silver, as one favour from the Pit.
— Hold then— now I think on't,
I'll e'en turn Thief, and steal your kind Affection,
And when I've got your Hearts, claim your protection:
You can't Gazette me sure for such a crime,
Since neither Mare nor Lap-dog, I purloin:
While you Rob Ladies Bosoms every day,
And filch their pretious Maiden-heads away;
I'll plead good nature for this Brat the Play:
A Play that plagues no more the thread-bare Theme
Of powder'd Beaux, or tricks o'th' Godly Dame,
But in your humours let's ye all alone,
And not so much as Fools themselves runs down.
Our Author try'd his best, and Wisemen tell,
'Tis half well doing to endeavour well:
What tho' his poor Allay runs not so fine;
Yet, let it pass as does our present Coin;
For wanting fairer Ore, and riches mould
He stamps in Brass, what others print in Gold:
Smile on him but this time, the next perhaps,
If he guess right he may deserve your Claps.

list.label: Bonvile, The Bridegroom.
Friendly, His Friend, in Love with Clara.
Justice Merryman, Father to Arabella.
Summerfield. A Gentleman, but Younger Brother, necessitated to take the High-way.
Mr. Ventre, A Merchant.
Mr. Spruce, A City Beau.
Compasse, A Master of a Vessel.
A Councellor.
Pettifog, Two Attorneys.
Dodge, Two Attorneys.
Sailers, Neighbours, Drawers, Servants, Boys, Singers and Dancers.
Arabella, The Bride.
Clara, Friendly's Mistriss, but secretly in Love with Bonvile.
Mrs. Ventre, The Merchant's Wife.
Peg. Compasses Wise.
Nurse.
Lucy, Clara's Maid.
Women Neighbours.

div.head: THE CITY BRIDE: OR, THE Merry Cuckold.
ACT I.
SCENE the I.
div.stage: The Curtain draws up, and discovers several sitting at a Banquet. An Entertainment of Instrumental Musick, Compos'd by Signior Finger: Then a Song▪ set by Mr. John Eccles, and Sung by Young La Roche.
div.l: MANY I've lik'd, and some Enjoy'd,
But if I said I Lov'd, I ly'd.
Inconstant as the wandring Bee,
From once touch'd Sweets I us'd to flee;
Nor all the Power of Female Skill,
Cou'd curb the freedom of my Will:
Clarinda only found the Art,
To Conquer and to keep my Heart.
div.stage: After this a Dance, and then the Scene shuts.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: THis is is a Day of Mirth and Jollity my Clara.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: 'Tis so, for such as can be merry, Mr. Friendly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why not for us my Love, we have a Noble President, and methinks shou'd Imitate (thrô Envy) this their happiness.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I am not of your Opinion.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why not my Fair?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I'll tell you, because I purpose not to Marry.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Prithee be serious, and reform that Thought: Think of my past Service, and judge by that my future; weigh all the respect I have paid you long, and ever lov'd you beyond my self.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I know your Weakness, and will reward it too.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I am sure you will, you must be kind; And can you think an Answer of this killing Nature, a just return for all my faithful Love?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: As to that I have already said.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh speak, from whence this Coldness doth arise! Be at least so kind as to tell me that; Is it some late Disgust you have conceived of my Person; or rather your desire, (I fear) of some unworthier, happy Creature, base in the Attempt, as you unkind in thinking of a Change; If neither.

lg.l: I must impute it to your Woman's Will,
Still pleased with what it fancies, Good or Ill.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Be't what it will, thus it is, and with this Answer pray rest satisfied; there is but one way ever to win me, and draw me unto Marriage, which whosoever finds, 'tis like he may have me, if not, I am still my own.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Oh name it then! Thou dearest Treasure of my Life! my Soul! my All! I am in a maze of Extasie, to think there's any means to gain you, and hope you'l be so kind to tell me how I may be happy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I'll retire a while; and with my self resolve what must be done, and in the tend send you my Resolution.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I'll here expect it: What more can I desire, than now be satisfied and know my Dooom.

lg.l: Suspence is the worst Torment we endure.
'Tis Knowledge makes the Wound both safe and sure.

sp.speaker: Spru.
sp.p: How now Iack! What all alone Man?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: No, for I have heard some say, Men are ne're less alone, then when alone. The reason I suppose is this, because they have Crowds of Thoughts, that still perplex the Mind; which wou'd be like the Soul retired and free, thereby to enjoy that sweet Repose, which nought but that can Grant.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Pshaw! Pox of this Morality and dull Stuff; Prithee let us be Merry, and Entertain the Bride and Bridegroom. Ods fish there a parcel of rare Creatures wihin! But of all Mrs. Clara for my Money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: And truly, I am of your Opinion Mr. Spruce; for setting aside her present Melancholly and Discontent, I think she is beyond Comparison with any other.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Od's nigs, I know the Cause of her Disorder.

sp.speaker: Vent.
sp.p: What I pray?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell ye; In all Conditions of Estates, Professions, and Degrees, in Arts or Sciences, yee know there's a kind of Envious Emulation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: So in this of Arabella's Marrying; for Clara being Lady of much the same Birth and Quality, Grieves I— suppose to see her Rival get the start of her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Troth like enough.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Y'are Pleasant Gentlemen— Or else because she having had so many Courtiers—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: And you among the rest Iack.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: She now perhaps does cast a more favourable Eye upon some one that does not like her.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why Faith, and that may be too.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir, my Mistriss presents her humble Service to you, and has sent you this Letter; pray Heaven it be to your liking Sir.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I thank the kind Lucy: There, there's for the Postage Girle: [Gives her Money.] She has kept her Promise for once I see; I'm resolved to read it, thô I were sure my Death was Comprehended in it.

body.p: Reads. Try all your Friends, and find out the best and nearest to your Heart, That done, be sure to kill him for my sake. This fail not to do, if you respect and Love (as you pretend.)

sp.p: 'Tis as I fear'd, and what I know she most desires: Mischief, and Murder, are all her Sexes Practice, and Delight? Yet such is the Extravagancy of my Passion, I must obey the Mandate, thô to my certain Ruine: 'Tis strangely difficult, and does require Mature Deliberation. Exit.

sp.speaker: Spr,
sp.p: What has Friendly left us?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: I believe the Letter was the occasion, it may be it was a Challenge.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: A Challenge! No, no; Women don't use to bring Challenges, I rather believe 'tis an Amour; And that Letter as you call it a Billet Deux, which is to Conduct him to the place appointed, and in some Sence you may take that for a Challenge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: And she the Civil Embassadress to usher him in.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but see the Bride and Bridegroom, with the rest of the good Company.

div.stage: Enter Iustice Merry-man, Bonvile, Arabella, Mrs. Venter and others, as Guests Invited to the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Son Bonvile, what call ye the Gentleman we met at the Garden Door?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Friendly Sir, a most approv'd and worthy Gentleman, and one of my chiefest Guests.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, ay, it may be so: But yet me thought he seemed somewhat displeased, thô Son, Hah, What think you?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: No sure Sir, he cannot be Angry, when his Friend's so happy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I can't tell Boy, but I believe there's something more than ordinary in the matter, Why should he leave the Company else? And Mrs. Clara I miss her too; Why Gentlemen, why do you suffer this?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Unknown to any Sir, she withdrew soon as we rise from Table.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sick of the Maid perhaps; because she sees you Mrs. Bride her Quondam Play-fellow Married before her, Heh Gentlemen; heh!

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: 'Troth like enough Brother Merry-man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Go, go, find her out for shame Gentlemen; and do not stand idle thus, Od's bobs, when I was a Young fellow and invited to a Wedding, I used to frisk and Jump, and so bestir my self, that I made all the Green-sickness Girles in the Room blush like Rubies. Ah, hah! I was a brisk Fellow in those Days, I'faith, and used to Cut Capers a Yard high: Nor am I yet so Old, but I can take a round or two still— Come, come Gentlemen, lets in again and firk it away, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Withall my Heart Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why that's well said Mr. Spruce, Ods bobs it was, and I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Come Madam, you must along with us, without you all's nothing.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I'll wait on you Gentlemen; if you will give me leave Sir. To Bonvile.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Oh my best Joy! This Day you may Command.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: That's right, that's right I'faith Gentlemen! This Day she Commands, and he for ever after. Ods bobs I have done so my self, and hope I shall do so still. Sister Venter, May I presume to ask if my Brother can say as much? Exit Bonvile, Arab. Spruce, and the rest of the Guests.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vent.
sp.p: Yes Brother, I think he may, I freely Give him leave.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Observe that Brother, she freely gives you leave: But who Gives leave the Master or the Servant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: You are Merry Brother, and truly you have reason, having but one Daughter and see her Married as you would have her.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, I have one thank Heaven! You wou'd be glad Sister you cou'd say so, but your Barrenness does give your Husband leave (if he please) to look for Game elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: Well, well Sir, thô you jeer me, and make a scorn of my Sterility—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, no, not I Sister, I scorn not your Sterility, nor your Husbands Virility neither.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: My Husband's Virility! Pray spare my Husband; for he has not been so Idle as you imagin; He may have an— Offspring abroad for ought you know, that you never heard of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Oh fye Wife, You will not make it publick will you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: And yet he keeps himself within compass for all that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: If you love me Winny—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: Na, I say no more, but thereby hangs a Tale.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Say'st thou so old Girle? What and has he been stragling then? Nay, nay I know he is a Ventersome Man; And a— Merchant of small Wares sometimes, especially when he can get a good Commodity: I love him the better for't I'faith, Ods bobs I do— A notable spark with a Young Wench in a corner, Is he not? A true Chip of the old Block, his Father I warrant him— But Sister, I have something to say to you in private, concerning my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: By your leave Good Folks, Is Master Venter the Merchant here I pray?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Oh Nurse! I am glad to see thee, How does my Boy?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Very well, I thank Heaven Sir! He grows bravely I assure you. 'Tis a Chopping Lad I promise you, and as like your good Worship; As if he had been spit out of your Mouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Softly, Nurse softly.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I protest 'tis one of the forward'st Infants in the Universe; Lord! how it will Crow, and Chirup like a Sparrow! I am afraid Sir he is about Teeth, for he Dribbles extreamly, if so, Your Worship must provide him a Silver Corral with a Whistle and Chain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Well, well, he shall have every thing Nurse, my Wife shall send them to ye; in the mean time, there, there's a Piece, to buy the a Pair of Gloves, and so leave us, for I am busie at present, therefore steal away behind me, and slip out at the back Door.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I am gone, Heavens bless your Worship, a Piece! Marry! and that's a sufficient Charm to lye up any Nurses Tongue in Christendom. Ex. Nurse.

sp.speaker: Iust. Mer.
sp.p: Well well, it shall be done. Come Brother we are mist I warrant you amongst the Young Fry, let's to 'um and, Dance till our Legs ake again, come I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: We follow you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Friendly Reading the the Letter.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Heaven in its excess of Goodness, bestow'd no greater Blessing on Mankind than that of Friendship— To Murder any one is a Crime unpardonable! But a Friend!— And of all Friends the nearest to my Heart,— 'Tis such an Imposition that Hell it self 'till now cou'd never parallel; And yet this Devil of a Woman has power over me beyond all Virtue. I am distracted in my Thoughts, and know not what to do; yet something must be done without delay, or else I lose her quite: And yet I fear 'tis most Impossible, for Friendship left the World, when Justice fled, and all who now do wear that Name are the worst of Hypocrites,
sp.l: Like Counterfeited Coin on which is seen,
The formal Stamp; but sordid Dross within.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My Friend alone and Thoughtful? say for what
That you alone appear with Discontent,
When all my Friends Congratulate my Bliss?
Is it because (which I durst ne're suspect)
Your Love to me was not intirely true?
Or else perhaps, this Crown of Happiness
You think Misplac'd, and Envy it not yours.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Forbear such cruel Words—
How can you entertain a Thought so Vile
Of him whom so long you have call'd your Friend▪
May all the Blessings Heaven can bestow
On us poor Mortals in this World below,
Crown all your Days, and may you nothing see
But flowing Tides of sweet Felicity;
But I, alas!—

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Alas! What means my Friendly?
Much hidden Grief that wretched Word portends,
Which thus disturbs the Quiet of my Friend?
But come disclose it to me,
And since the Burthen is too much for one,
I'll bear a part to ease thy troubled Breast.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Oh Bonvile!
Seek not to force this Fatal secret from me—

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I must know it, by my best hopes I must.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Oh no! I cannot, Nay I dare not—

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: How dare not trust a secret to a Friend?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Oh Bonville, Bonville! Call me not your Friend,
That Names strikes horrour to my very Soul.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Ha! Art thou then a Stranger to that Name?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Indeed I am, and must be so for ever now.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Yet hear me Friendly; Deny me if thou can'st,
Fixt as a Rock, I vow I'll here remain,
Until I have forc'd this Dire secret from thee.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Pardon me Sir, I hope you soon will hear it,
But I— [Offers to go.]

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Yet stay, and since intreaty can't prevail,
By all the Friendship which you once profess'd,
By all that's Holy, both in Heaven and Earth,
I now Conjure thee to impart it to me,
Or by this Life—
Hold, hold, and since I can no longer hide it
Know 'tis my Honour then which lyes at Stake.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Thy Honour! How? Proceed.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: By chance a Quarrel happen'd to arise
Betwixt another and my self, The Field,
Time, Place, and all appointed,
Nay Seconds must assist us in the Deed:
I have relied on many seeming Friends,
Such as profess the bare and empty Name)
And all refuse to venture in my Cause.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: All, Is it not enough? To see my Reputation, (the Lifes Blood of my Soul)
Nay all that's Dear, in Danger to be lost.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Not while thy Bonvile lives and wears a Sword:
May all things frown that I wou'd have to smile,
May I live Poor, and Dye despised by all,
If I out live the ruine of thy Honour!
Tell me the time my Friend?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Oh, spare me that, for, if once known the time,
You'l Cancel this your promise, and recall
Your Friendly proffer.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Away with these Excuses, come the time

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: At Seven this Evening

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The place?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Barn-Elms:
Oh the fatal place! Where I too well foresee,
The certain fall and Ruine of my Honour!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: No, Thou shalt not stay to forfeit thy lov'd Honour,
Come I'm ready to assist my Friend; and will along with you.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Alas! What mean you?
Of all my Friends on you I ne're Relied;
But sure I Dream, I Rave, by Heav'ns I'm Mad!
My Bonvile leave his Wife? And on his Wedding Day?
His Bride whom he perhaps may ne're Enjoy?
And all for me? O most unhappy Man!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Pleasure before my Friend I'll ne're prefer,
Nor is it lost, thô for a while delay'd.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Are you then resolv'd to go?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I am, as fixt in my Resolve, as is the Libertin in Vice,
Which Death alone can part.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yet stay, and think what it is you undertake,
Recall this Rash and suddain Resolution,
Least you repent, alas when it is too late.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: This were enough to shake a weaker Soul,
But mine it moves not; like to a Mighty Oake,
I'm plac'd above the Storms of Fear or Doubt.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Sir no more, the Bride,

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: Oh, Heavens defend me!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What ailes my Dearest Life?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: I've lost the Key of this Chain I wear about my Neck
And of these Bracelets, Oh! Unhappy Omen!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: No, no, my Love; I found it as it lay at Random in your Chamber, and fearing it might be forgot, or lost, have laid it by; 'Tis safe my Love.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: Indeed I'me very glad you've found it, but yet— sighs.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Yet, What my Dear? from whence proceeds that sigh?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.l: Alas, I know not!
Some busie Genius Whispers to my Soul,
The loss of this upon my Wedding Day
Portend's a greater e're the Day be past.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Banish such Fears, let's in and see our Friends.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: Indeed they all expect you; come I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I'll go with you. Barn-Elms you say? Aside to Friendly.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yes that's the place, at Seven precisely;

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I'll meet you on the Exchange, and go together;
If you are there before me, Take a turn or two. Exit Bonvile, and Arabella.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Oh my Dear Bonvile! Art thou then the Man?
The only, only Man that I can call Friend,
And only Friend that I am bound to Kill?
A Friend, that for my sake wou'd stake his Life,
Leave a Chast Brid! and untouch'd Nuptial Bed
For me base Man, nay worse than Savage Beast:
The generous Lyon, never kills his kind
They say, althô provoked to utmost rage;
Yet I vile Monster, more ungrateful Man,
Thus unprovoked, must kill my Brother Creature,
And which is worse, my Dear and only Friend!
All for the pleasure of a Foolish Woman.

lg.l: O cruel Woman thus to Command
A Task so hard, Yet what I can't withstand!
Oh! thou rare Copy of the Original,
By which free Man at first received his fall;
For she not only wou'd her self undo,
And all her Sex, but Damn all Mankind too. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT the Second.
SCENE the First. The Fields.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: A Younger Brother! 'Tis a poor Title, and very hard to bear with: The Elder Fool inherits all the Land, whilst we are forc'd to follow Legacies of Wit, and get 'um when we can. Why shou'd the Law, by which we are deprived of equal Portion with the First-begotten, not bind our Fathers to cease from Procreation, and so as well deprive us of a wretched Being, as of the Thing we cannot be without: No, no, our Mothers ne're will consent to that, they love to groan and squall, tho at the same time the Gallows eccho's to their Groans, and both together labour for us. From the first we travel forth— to'thers our Journey's End. All this I know, yet I must forward: To beg, my Birth will ne're consent to; and borrowing is quite out of date— Yet starve I cannot, nor murder I wou'd not: It must be the High-way then, the old Trade we poor honest Rogues are forc'd too— This Place will serve for a Beginner well enough— A Beginner did I say? Yes; for this is the very first day I open Shop— Fortune, they say, uses to help the Bold, I hope she will be kind to me. Ha! who have we here? A Gentlewoman well rigg'd, and only a Servant with her, She may be a Prize worth the boarding, and faith I'll venture hard but I'll carry her. He retires to a corner of the Stage.

div.stage: Enter Arabella in great disorder, looking about her, with Symon her Servant.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: This way, say'st thou Symon, with Friendly?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Yes forsooth Mistress, with Mr. Friendly.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Alas! I'm tired and cannot travel further; my Heart is full of Fear, and yet I know not why, nor can I tell why he should use me thus;— It is not common sure for Men to leave their Brides upon the Wedding-day: And yet I cannot tell but it may be so! O wretched State of Marriage, and of Love, if this be Love! Here will I lie me down, and rest a while [Lies down.] my wearied Limbs, unused to these sad Frights and Fears— But prethee do thou run after him, and if it be possible o'retake him too: Tell him the strange Disorder thou dost leave me in; and let him know my Father's Anger, his Friends Concern, and what is more, his Arabella's sad Complaint; tell him, I grieve, I faint, I die; tell him any thing that may stay him.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Yes Forsooth.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Intreat him to return; nay, urge him all thou canst to make him come again: Nay haste, good Symon, fly if thou canst, for I can stir no further.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Well, well, Forsooth, I am gone. Exit Symon.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Alas, how wretched and forlorn am I!

lg.l: I she whom once so many did admire,
Whose Wit and Charms the coldest Hearts cou'd fire!
Now wretched Maid, and most unhappy Wife,
In Sighs and in Complaints must end my Life.
Abandoned by my Husband▪ e're enjoy'd,
With thoughts of Pleasure, yet untasted, cloy'd.
He leaves me now to my sad Frights a Prey;
O, my dear Bonvile! whither dost thou stray?
Vnheard, alas! I make my amarous Moans;
The Winds and Waves refuse to bear my Groans:
Eccho her self can't suffer my Complaint,
But with repeated Sighs grows tir'd and faint.
Where to find him, good Heaven direct me!
For losing him, I more than lose my self. Rises, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I must after her, she's worth my Acquaintance, and has good Moveables about her I perceive, what e're the Ready is. The next Turning has a most convenient Hollow for the Purpose, and there I'll make her sure. Now Luck, or never.

div.stage: Reenter Arabella, and Summerfield after her.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I'm at a stand already, and know not where I am.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I'll direct you, Madam; Well overtaken.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir, What are you?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: A Man.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: An honest Man, I hope?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Yes faith in some Respects, I'm very honest, but not altogether so; I were not fit to live in the World if I were too honest, Child.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Alas! then I begin to fear: Pray tell me what you are?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Why, faith, an honest Thief.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: How, honest, and yet a Thief? I never heard they were of Kin before; Pray, Heaven, I find it now.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Indeed I a very honest Thief.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since that's your Title, pray use me kindly: Nay, I'm sure you will, there's something in your Looks which speaks you mild and noble.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Yes, I am a Gentleman, and you shall find me so; for I'll not offer you the least shew of Violence, or offer to corrupt your Chastity; tho indeed you are tempting Eair, and might inflame a colder Heart than mine: Yet Ravishing's no part of my Profession as yet; or if it were, you look so charming Innocent, you wou'd disarm my wildest Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Blessings on your Goodness!

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Are you a Maid, or Wife?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I am both, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Then this it seems is your Wedding-day, and these the Hours of Interim that keep you in that double State?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Indeed you are in the right.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Come then, I'll be brief, and hinder not your desired Hymen. You have some superfluous Toys I see about you, which you must deliver; I mean, that Chain of Gold and Pearl about your Neck, and those pretty Bracelets about your Arms, (pray, Heaven, they prove not Emblems of the combined Hemp which is to halter mine); come, Madam, pray deliver 'em.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Nay, I intreat you, Sir, to take 'em, for I cannot give 'em, they are lock'd you see, and truly I have not the Key about me; it may be you are furnish'd with Instruments that may unloose 'em, I pray do.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: No faith, Madam, I'm but a Beginner in this same Business, and am wholly unprovided of any Pick-lock Tools besides this Sword. Draws his Sword.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: O, good Sir, do not shew me that, 'tis too frightful; pray hurt me not, for I do yield them freely: Use your Hands, perhaps their strength will serve to tear 'em from me without more ado. Some Pain I'll quietly endure, provide you do not hurt me much.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Alas, dear Lady, I'll use you as gently as I can He endeavours to break the Chain about her Neck. upon my Word; but 'tis devilish strong— if I hurt you, pray speak.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Not much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I am glad on't,— S'death, I can't do it. She draws his Sword, and stands upon her Guard.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: No Sir, nor shall not now: You a Highway-man and guard your self no better: Come, Sir, what Money have you? Deliver quickly.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Not a Cross by this foolish Hand of mine!

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: How, no Money, 'twere pity then to take this from thee; Gives him his Sword again. Here, take it again, I know you'l use me ne're the worse for what I have done.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: No, by my Life!

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I do believe you, and now pray hear me— Here on my Knees, in sight of Heaven, I make this solemn Protestation, That if you'l but forbear the Rifling of this Chain and Bracelets, and go but with me Home, by all the Vows which I this Day have plighted to my dearest Husband, I will deliver you in Money the full Value of these I wear, and cannot for my Life get off.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Ha! Ready-money is the Prize I look for; it passes without suspicion every where, when Chains and Jewels are often stop'd and call'd for before the Magistrate: But—

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Nay never doubt! You saw I gave you my Advantage up, and questioned not my safety at your hands, pray fear not yours in mine.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I know not what to do.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Pray tell me, Sir, did you ever think a Woman true?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I have heard of some, but very few.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Will you add one more to your belief?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I think I may, for they were fewer than the Articles of my Faith, therefore I have room for you, and will believe you— Yet stay, you say you'l ransom your Jewels with Ready-money when you come Home; so you may, and then discover me.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Shall I repeat the Vows I made?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: No, for I'll trust you; and if you do betray me, then Mercy upon me, and Farewel. I knew a Gentleman that had been a Courtier at Whitehall fifteen Years, and he was buried e're he took a Bride: 'Tis very strange you'l say; and may be my Case in another way.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Come, Sir, never fear: A Man and afraid; Fie, fie!

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Give me your Hand, I'll wait on you; and if you are (as I believe you) True and Just, you are the World's Wonder! Come, Madam. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter two Boys, one with a Child in his Arms. Compass on the other side.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Iack, Who's this?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: O Ieminy! I'll be hang'd if it ben't Goodman Compass, that they said was dead three Years ago.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Od's Life, and so it is!

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O London! sweet London! Do I live to see thee once again? My Eyes are full of Brine for Joy. And if my dear Peggy be but living still, I shall cry 'em out.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Goodman Compass, I am glad to see you; You are welcome home.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thank you, good Lad: Honest Iack here too? Why, thou art grown a little Man since I saw thee last: What, is that thy own, heh?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: I am fain to keep it, you see, whoever got it; it may be other Mens Cases as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou say'st true Iack: But whos's pretty Knave is it?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: My Dame's where I live.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And not thy Master's?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I can't tell that neither: My Master loves it as well as if it were his own, and for ought I see better than my Dame.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A very good Lad by my Troth!

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: But, Goodman Compass, I can tell you News, Your Wife has a brave Boy too of her own, not above a Quarter old, as big as two of this.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ha! say'st thou so, Iack? Ha, ha, ha, by my Troth I am heartily glad to hear it: I'll give thee a dozen of Ale, and thy News be true, Boy.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: I assure you 'tis very true: All your Neighbours can tell you the same.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! But a Quarter old, and so lusty, say you? What plaguy thundering Boys are got now-a-days: I Gad, I shall split my Sides with Laughing; Ha, ha, ha.— But, Iack, I have been loth to ask thee all this while, for fear of ill News, how does my Wife?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: O never better, nor ever so lusty and handsome— And truly she wears better Clothes than she was wont, especially on Holy-days: she has Silk-Gowns, and Lac'd-Petticoats, and fine Holland-Smocks too, they say, that have seen 'em: And some of our Neighbours say, they were taken up in Cheat

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Like enough, Iack; and there they must be paid for— Well, good Lads, go and tell my Wife the joyful Tidings of my Return.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: That I will with all my Heart, for she heard you were dead long ago.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Nay, I'll go along with you Iack.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Come then. Exeunt 2 Boys.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well, Peggy, if I am one of the Livery, I thank thee for it: The Cuckolds are the greatest Company in all the City: And we have more Aldermen among us, than all the other put them together.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O my dear sweet Honey-suckle! Art thou alive? I am glad Runs and kisses him. to see thee with all my Heart and Soul, so I am.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O, ho! good Spouse, give me leave to shed a few pearly Tears; the Fountain of Love will have its Course: And thô I cannot Sing at first sight, yet I can Cry you see. I am as it were new come into the World; and Children Cry before they Laugh, a long time you know.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes; and so thou art new born indeed to me, my Numpy; for I was told you were dead long since, and never thought to see this dear sweet Face of thine again: I heard thou wert div'd to the bottom of the Sea, and that you never did intend to see poor Peggy more.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: He, he, he, I was going down, as you say Peg, but I thought better on't, and turn'd back: I heard an ill Report of my Neighbours there; the devouring Sharks, and other Sea-Monsters, whose Company, to tell you the Truth, I did not like; and therefore resolv'd to come home and bide with thee my Girl— Come kiss thy poor Hubby, kiss me I say, for Sorrow begins to ebb apace.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: A thousand, thousand Welcomes home dear Numpy!

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: An Ocean of Thanks, kind Peggy: Well, and how goes all at Home? What Lank still, poor Peg? Wil't ne're be full Sea at our Wharf?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Alas, Husband, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A Lass is it, or a Lad, Wench? I shou'd be glad of both; I look'd for a pair of Compasses long afore now.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What, and you from home, Love?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I from home? Why thô I was from home, and other of our Neighbours from home, does that follow that every body else is from home?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I am pleased you are so merry, Husband.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Merry, nay I'll be merrier yet; why shou'd I be sorry? I hope my Boy's well, is he not? Od's fish, I look for another by this Time.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Boy, what Boy, Deary?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What Boy! why the Boy I got when I came home in the Cock-boat one Night, about a Year ago; You have not forgotten it, I hope, I think I left behind me for a Boy, and a Boy I look for.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: I find he knows all— What shall I do? [Aside.]
O dear Husband, pray pardon me. [Kneels.]

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Pardon thee; why I hope thou hast not made away with my Boy, hast thou? Od's death I'll hang thee, if there were never a Whore more in London, if thou hast.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O no; but your long Absence, and the Rumour of your Death, [Cries.] made me think I might venture.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Venture, quoth a, I can't blame thee Peg; for Wapping, if it were twice Wapping, can't hold out always, no more than Redriff, Limehouse or Shadwel, nay or the strongest Suburbs about London; and when it comes to that, wo be to the City too, Girl.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Consider, Husband, I'm but a Woman, neither the first or last that have done the same; and truly I won't deny but I have a Child.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Have you so? And what by Consequence must I have then, I pray?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: If you'l forgive me this Time, it shall be so no more, indeed and indeed, now.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well, well, I will forgive thee, Peg, upon this Condition, that you tell me who it was that fell foul aboard thee, and sprung this Leak in thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O dear Husband!

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, no Excuses, for I must know.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Why then truly it was Mr. Venter the Merchant.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I am beholding to him, and wou'd requite his Civility, if his Wife were but as willing, thô he be one of our Merchants at Sea, he shall give me leave to be Owner at home; and where is my Boy? what, shan't I see him?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes if you please, good Husband: He's nurs'd at Bednal green; 'tis now too late, to Morrow will be better.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Come then we'l home and to bed.

lg.l: Let other Fools repine at Scoffs and Scorns,
I'll teach the Cuckold how to hide his Horns. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Iustice Merryman, Mr. Venter, Spruce, Mrs. Venter and Clara.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Was the like ever known, that a Bridegroom shou'd absent himself on his Wedding-Day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: 'Tis somewhat strange indeed.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And the Bride too my Daughter, she's out of the way: Why what shou'd be the meaning of all this, Od's bobs I can't tell?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: Perhaps they'r busy Brother, privately conferring Notes together: You can't tell but that the young Man may have a stomach to his Supper, and fall too unawares, and we ne're the wiser.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Od's nigs, very true; what wou'd you say then Sir, if they shou'd be stol'n away, and a-bed together seriously?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What wou'd I say? marry I wou'd say, Speed 'em well: And if no worse News ever comes to me, I'll be hang'd if e're I cry'd for't.
How now, what's the Business with you?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Business enough, Forsooth; for I have the strangest Tydings!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Of any One that's lost, Woman?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: No forsooth, of One that's found again, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O, he was lost then it seems.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Her Business is with me, I believe Brother; is it not, Woman?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.l: Come hither then, [Nurse whispers Mr. Venter.]
How, return'd?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir, and all discovered.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Ah Curse on the Wind that blew him ashore.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Aye▪ so say I Sir, and did not sink him when he was going.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Well, well, be sure you do not let him come near the Child.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, if you charge me to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Yes, I do strictly charge you as you tender my Displeasure.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Well then let me alone— Besides, Sir, he intends to come to morrow morning with his Wife and see him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: I'll meet him there; and if he chance to be there before me, be sure to keep the Child safe, and not let him touch it.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I warrant you, let me alone. Exit Nurse.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So, so, Heaven be praised, they are not both lost I see, here's the Bride, my Daughter, come again.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Father, and Gentlemen, I desire ye to treat this Stranger here with all Respect and Generosity: He's a loving Kinsman of my Bonvile's, who kindly came to congratulate our Wedding.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sir, you are heartily welcome, Od's bobs you are.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Welcome to all of us.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Seriously, Sir, and so you are.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But where's the Bridegroom, Girl? Od's bobs we're all at a Nonplus here, at a stand, quite out; the Musicks ceas'd, and we all look as thô there were neither a light Heart or Heel among us; nay, my Cousin Clara too as cloudy as on a washing Day.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: 'Tis then because you will not dance with me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: 'Tis I alone have cause to be sad, if this Day's Happiness cou'd admit of any: But I've long reason'd with my pressing Thoughts, and from them drawn some Symptoms of Relief. Suppose this Day hath been long since appointed by my dear Bonvile, to meet some foe, and right his injur'd Reputation: Nay, say he fights, alas! Why shou'd I fear, when all the Powers above, that guard true Love and Innocence, will never see him fall.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prethce peace, good Girl hold thy tongue; Od's bobs thou'lt make us all Cowards, to hear a Woman preach up Valour thus.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I have done: But pray entertain this Gentleman kindly for my sake. Indeed I was afraid when I saw him first.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Ha! what does she say? Od's Death she'l tell!

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Being in search of my dear Bonvile, I had quite lost my Way when he most opportunely came unto my Aid, and gave me many marks of his Esteem in my distress of Fears; nay more than this, which I'll declare at large.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Death and Hell, she'l betray me.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, since the Bridegroom's absent, I must supply his Place: Come, when I have waited on you to your Pleasure, I will return to [To Summerfield.] you, Sir, we must discourse more of my Bonvile yet.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: What a trembling Trade's this, when Conscience, that shou'd be our only Guide, flies and leaves us to our accusing Guilt. A Thief! the very Name and Thought chills my Blood, and makes me tremble like an Ague-fit. A Dog, nay every Bough that moves, puts us in fear of present Apprehension. Sure I shall never thrive on this Trade: Perhaps I need take no further Care, I may be now near to my Journey's End, or at least in a fair way to Newgate, and from thence to Tyburn, the only Place that we poor Rogues can claim for an Inheritance. Trust a Woman, and with a Matter of such Importance, what a simple Dog am I? I cou'd find in my Heart to run away: And that were base to run from a Woman; I can lay claim to nothing but her Vows, and those the Women seldom or never mind.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: So, Sir, now you shall find a Woman as good as her Promise; Here are 20 Pieces, the full Value, on my Life, of what they cost.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, do not thus suspend my doubtful Soul; but if you do design to insnare my Life, speak, speak freely: Or if the Constable be at the Door, let him shew his Staff of Authority, perhaps I may corrupt him with a Bribe.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: How! base ungrateful Man, do you suspect my Faith? Nay then, Father, Uncle, and Gentlemen, where are you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How now, how now! What's the matter, Girl?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: For shame, will you not entertain your Kinsman here a little better; you leave him here alone, as thô you despised his Company.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is that all? I thought the Bridegroom had been return'd: Sir, pray pardon this Rudeness; But indeed I had quite forgot you, quite forgot you, as I hope to be sav'd: But what makes you tremble, Sir, are you ill dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Think you he hath not reason to be ill-disposed at this cold Aside to Iustice Merryman. Entertainment? for my part I blush for shame.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Come pray, Sir, shake off this Dulness, and participate of our
Mirth, Od's nigs do.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I am very well, Sir, I thank you, only the Gentleman is a little under a Mistake.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: It may be so, Ay, ay, it may be so; I vow I thought you had trembled, but I believe it might be my own Hand; you must pardon me, I was stiffer once.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But, Gentlemen, what think you of an Adventure?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Adventure whither?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why, to the East-Indies? I have a Vessel, Gentlemen, called the Sea-Horse, bound thither, and to morrow I do expect her to sail. Now, Gentlemen, if you'l venture, ye shall have fair Dealing, that I'll promise you. And for the French, you need not fear them▪ for she is a smart new Vessel: Nay, she hath a Letter of Mart too, and twenty brave roaring Boys on both Sides her, Starboard and Larboard: And I intend to go as far as Marget down with her, 'twill be as good as Physick to me.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: A very good Motion, Sir, I begin, there's my ten Pieces.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: And, Sir, if a proffer'd Love may be accepted, be pleased to take my ten Pieces with you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Your's above all the rest, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: That's kindly said, Sir, and I thank you: Now pray venture Ten more for my sake.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, it's a younger Brother's Portion.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: At my Request, Sir, venture the other Ten; if you want, I'll supply you with as many more.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: With all my Heart then: Come, Sir, if you please, I'll double mine: So now she's got her Gold again, and I am now no Thief, (aside) Sir, I have a Suit to you,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You may command it, for I am always at your Service: But pray your Pleasure?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: My Request, Sir, is, to have the Honour of keeping you Company to Sea, for I have a great desire to see Marget.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be very happy in your good Company.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I hope you will be both better acquainted e're you return; and by that time your Kinsman may be here to make you more welcome.

lg.l: And for the Gold at my Request you lent,
I'll double it to give you more content.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: Why shou'd I fear, since she is prov'd so just?
I'll quit my Trade: Now Jack Catch do thy worst.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: ACT the Third. A Wood.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: COME my brave Friendly, I think we are here the first: Your Enemy is not yet i'th Field; let's walk a Turn or two, perhaps by that time he may arrive.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I'm very confident that he's here already.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Thy Looks, me-thinks, speak Conquest sure thy own; an ardent Rage has kindled both thy Cheeks.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Like a red Morning, Friend; which still foretels a stormy Day to follow— And now I well observe your Face, me-thinks it waxes pale, there's Death in it already.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: How, Friendly, do you then take me for a Coward? My face look pale, and Death in it already? By Heav'n, shou'd any but my Friendly dare to tell me what thou hast said, my Sword shou'd ram the base Affront down the curst Villain's Throat. But you are my Friend, and I must only chide your Error. But prethee tell me who is it you are to fight with, for as yet I am ignorant both of the Cause and Person.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Ha, his Name! Did you enquire his Name?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I dare not yet reveal it for fear of—

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: For fear of what?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: O Confusion! I know not what to say!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: How, afraid to tell his Name? Then I begin to doubt the Justice of your Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Too well you may, for by yon' setting Sun, that Globe of heavenly Light I swear, I come to kill the only Man that strives to save my Life— Man did I say? Nay more than common Man, for those the World abound with; but such a Man besides, all this vast Land affords not.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: By this your large Encomium of your Friend, I'm afraid 'twas Wine first made your Quarrel, and thereupon this Challenge did ensue.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: O no! I call the Powers above to witness, that in all the Course of our unhappy Friendship, I to my knowledg never did receive the least Affront or Injury from him.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: How came this Challenge then?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p:
O dear Friend, the noblest that Man cou'd ever boast of: [embraces him] When first my rigid Fate threw on me this Command to fight, I had recourse to many whom I always thought my Friends▪ but when the Touchstone of my Danger try'd 'em, I found 'em like the cursed Fruit of Sodom, fair without, but rotten at
the Heart: But then I found out Bonvile, my only dearest Friend. Bonvile no sooner heard of my Engagement, but flew unto my Succour with as much Bravery, as a great General hastned by Alarms, marches to meet the Foe: You left your Nuptial Bed perhaps to meet your Death. O unheard-of Friendship! My Father gave me Life, 'tis true; but you, my Friend, support my Honour. All this for me, while I, ungrateful Man, thus seek your Life: For to my eternal Horror be it spoke, you are the Man whom I come here to kill.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Too true alas! there read the Warrant for your Death. Gives him the Letter.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: 'Tis a Woman's Hand.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Yes, and a bad One too, they all speak fair, write foul, but mean worse.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: How! kill me? Sure, I dream, and this is all Delusion, or else thou dost it only to try thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: O, from my Soul, I wish it were no more. But read, read on, see how I'm fetter'd in a Circe's Charms— I love beyond Imagination, love even to Madness, and must as madly do a Deed will damn me to the hottest Flames of Hell.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: And woo't thou kill thy Friend for such a Woman?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Alas! I must, you see I am commanded, commanded too by Love; Love more powerful than all the Sacred Ties of Friendship, therefore draw, and guard thy self. Draws.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Not I by Heaven! What wou'dst thou have me draw and kill my Friend?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: There thou stab'st my Soul. O where, where is now my Resolution fled? A fatal Blast has struck me; a suddén Horror shot me thrô the Heart; a Trembling seiz'd my Knees, that I can hardly stand, and all my Vital Powers methinks seem dead; yet Love's the Fire must kindle all again, therefore I charge thee draw, or naked as thou art, I will assail thee.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I am defended against all that thou canst do, in having Justice on my Side, and Friendship too to back it.
sp.l: But since Humanity now bears so sway,
To this unguarded Breast come make your way.
sp.p: Strike home be sure. Opens his Bosom.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: That were a barbarous Murder.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: How can the Effect prove different from the Cause? Or how can any thing but damn'd Barbarity ensue a Woman's much more damn'd Design? Who wou'd expect Reason from one that raves, or hope for Mercy in a Tyger's Den? Believe me, Friendly, all this may sooner be; Mercy may sooner dwell among the Salvage Wolves and Bears, than in a Woman's Breast.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: O, my too rigid Fate, to place me thus on such a dangerous Precipice, that wheresoe're I turn my self for help, I see my Ruin still before mine Eyes. Seems to weep.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: [Pausing.] Stay— The Command which thy Medea sent thee, was to kill thy only dearest Friend, was it not?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Alas! it was.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Then here, all Friendship dies between us; thus hast thou kill'd thy Friend, and satisfied that infernal Hag, thy cursed Mistress, who thus commanded thee: Away, I say, begon, and never see me more.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Yes, base ungrateful Wretch, farewel, (Offers to go)— Yet stay, and since that Sacred Tie of Friendship's broke, know thou, most vile of Men, that Bonvile's now thy Enemy; therefore do thou draw and guard thy spotted Life.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: How, Friend!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Friend didst thou call me? On forfeit of thy Life that word no more; the very Name of Friend from thee, shall be a Quarrel: How can I tell but that thou lovest my Wife, and therefore feign'd this damn'd Design to draw me from her Arms?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: How! wrong thy Wife? O no, I never had a Thought so vile! Yet you must forgive me, indeed you must, by all that once was dear to me; and what I dare not mention more, by Love and Honour, I implore thy Pardon— Still art thou deaf to my Complaints?— Nay, then upon my Knees I will enforce thy Pity. Behold me, Bonvile, prostrate at thy Feet, crawling for Mercy, swimming in Tears, and almost drown'd with Shame; extend thy Arm to help me, as thou'rt a Man, be God-like in thy Nature, and raise me from the Grave; turn thy Eyes on me, and sink me not with Frowns; O save me, save me, or I fall for ever.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: As soon shall Heav'n reverse the Fate of Hell, as I recal what I have said, or plant thee in my Breast again.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Nay, then I am lost to thee, and all the World besides. Rises.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Thou art indeed for ever lost to me; see what a miserable Wretch thy Folly now has made thee: A Creature so far below my Pity, that I despise and scorn thy base Submission, and will never hear thee more, more.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Say but thou hast forgiven me, and I will ask no more.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I never will.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: O cruel Bonvile!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: More barbarous Friendly: Hold off, or I will use thee like a Dog, tread thee to Earth, and spurn thee like a Slave, base as thou art.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Still thou art my Friend—

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Thou ly'st, I have abjured the Name.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Let me but go with thee.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Not for the World; I'de rather venture my self with Crocodiles, catch the last dying Gasps of some poor Wretch infected with the Plague, than trust my self with thee.

lg.l: Farewel, I leave thee with the greatest Curse,
Condemn'd to Woman, Hell affords no worse.

div.stage: Friendly solus, rising in a Passion.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Death and Destruction, am I thus despised! Condemned to Woman's Lust, and scorn'd by Man. By Bonvile too, after imploring, like a School-Boy, at his Feet— My Blood boils high, and scalds my very Heart! My inward Grief calls on me for Revenge, and I am all on fire! O that I had the proud Bonvile here now at my Feet, I'de use him worse than he did me before.

lg.l: But since that open Force yields no Relief,
Private Revenge shall ease my swelling Grief.
With Thoughts of Iealousy I'll fill his Soul,
Which shall its Powers of all their Rest controul.
Thus for a Woman I've begun a War,
And for her sake must damn my Soul like her. Exit.

div.head: SCENE the Second.
div.stage: Enter Nurse, Compass, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Indeed you must pardon me, I can't let ye see the Child; to tell you the Truth, I am commanded to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Commanded! Prethee who commanded thee?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: The Father.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: The Father, Why who am I?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Not the Father sure, the Civil Law has found it otherwise.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: The Civil Law found it otherwise! Why then the Uncivil Law shall make it mine again, I'll be as dreadful as a Shrove-Tuesday to thee; for I'll besiege thy squalling catterwauling Castle, with my Friends the Mob, and gut thy stinking Nursery, but I'll both see and have my Child.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Harkee, Goodman Swabber, say but half so much again, and I'll call the Constable, and lay Burglary to your Charge. You wou'd not be so hot if the Enemy were in view, nor if you had to do with any body but a poor innocent Woman, so you wou'd'nt.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Good Husband be patient, and let me alone with her: Come, come, good Nurse, let him see the Boy.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Indeed I dare not Goody Compass: The Father first you know delivered me the Child, and order'd me to let no body see it. He pays me well and weekly for my Pains, and therefore I'll do as he bad me, so I will.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Why thou white Bastard-breeder; Is not this Woman here the Mother?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Yes; I grant you that.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Do you so? Well, and I grant it too; And is not the Child then my own by the Wives Copy-hold?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: The Law must try that.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: The Law! What then you think I'll be but its Father-in-Law? I tell thee, all the Wit and Law 'twixt Cuckolds-Point and Westminster-Hall, shan't keep my own dear Flesh and Blood from me, I warrant you that. No an't does, I'll be hanged at the Main-yard: Why, who, dost think, uses to get my Children but my self?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Nay, I can't tell, you must look to that, for my part I ne're knew you get any.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Say'st thou so? Why, look you, do but put on a clean Smock, and try me, if thou darst, I'll hold thee three to one I get thee with Child before I leave thee: Heh! what say'st thou? Offers to lay hold on her.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I'll see you hang'd first— Nay, pray be quiet, and don't offer to spoil my Milk. Lord, you are as boisterous as my Husband was the first Night we were married: Pray, Goody Compass, take off your Cur, or else he'l bite me.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No never fear him, Nurse, he's not so furious I assure ye.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Venter and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: O! here's my Master, the Child's Father, now talk with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Good morrow Neighbour, good morrow to ye both.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Both! Good morrow to you and your Wife too, if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: I wou'd speak calmly with you, Friend, if you think fit.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I know what belongs to Calm, and a Storm too; and if you please, a cold word or two wi' you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I understand that you have ty'd your Mare in my Ground.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: My Mare, Friend, nay I assure you 'twas only my Nag.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Your Nag? Well your Nag then let it be: Harke, Sir, to be short, I'll cut off your Nag's Tail, if-e're I catch him there again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Pray hear me, you are too rough to maintain—

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I say, Sir, you shall maintain no Child of mine; my Wife does not bestow her Labour for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: You are too passionate—. I will not maintain—

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No marry shall you not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: The Deed I have done to be lawful, I have repented it, and given Satisfaction to the Law, my Purse has paid for't; therefore I wou'd treat milder with you if you'd be pleased.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am very well pleased, and shall be better pleased if you can serve me so still: For, look you Sir, one of these Days I shall to Sea again, you know where my Wife lives; yet you'l but lose your labour, for get as many Children as you can, I assure you, you shall keep none of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: I think you are mad.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Why, if I am Horn mad, what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Nay then, since you are so rough, I tell you plainly you are— a—

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A what? What am I, heh?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: A Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: A Coxcomb! a Cuckold you mean, and you a Fool for your pains.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: The Child is mine, I am the Father of it, and will keep it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Yes if you can, I know you will. But pray tell me, is not my Wife the Mother? You may be as far from being the Father as I am, for my Wife's acquainted with more Whore-masters besides your self; ay, and as crafty Merchants too, let me tell you that.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No indeed Husband, I had to do with no body else, 'twas he begot, indeed and indeed now. Yet for all that, the Child's mine, I bred it and bore it, and I'll have it and keep it, so I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: Pray hold there Mrs. Jill-flurt, the Child's my Husband's, and he shall have it, or I'll tear your Eyes out, ye Whore you.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Good Words, Mistress; d'ye hear, give good Words you'd best, or I shall tell you your own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: I'll have no more to say to ye, the Law shall determine it; in the mean time Nurse keep the Child for me, there, there's Money for thee. Gives her Money.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: There's Money for me too, keep it for me, Nurse; give him both thy Duggs at once, I pay thee for the right one, Girl.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I have two Hands, you see Gentlemen; this does but shew ye how the Law will hamper ye; even thus you'l be used, Gentlemen, if you go to Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: It can't be helpt, for I won't lose my Right.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nor I mine for all you're a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: Nor I mine for all I did not bear it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nor I, thô but a poor Sailer's Wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Well, fare ye well, we shall meet in another Place— Come Winny.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'll meet you when and where you dare, and do your worst, I fear you not: By the Lord Harry the World's come to a fine Pass, that we must go to Law for our Children. No wonder the Lawyers are all so rich, yet e're the Law shall have a Limb, a Leg, a Joint or Nail of this same Boy,
sp.l: 'Tshall cost me more than a whole Child in getting,
Some win by play, and standers by with Betting.

div.head: SCENE the Third.
div.stage: Enter Spruce, Arabella with a Letter in her Hand, Clara, Mr. Venter, and Mrs. Venter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: From whence came that Letter, Niece?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: From Putney, Sir, and from my Husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: And pray be free; Does he tell ye the Cause of his leaving you so abruptly on his Wedding-day?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, yet this had been sufficient to have let me known what he is gone about, without the formal Addition of an Epistle.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: That, why what is that I pray Madam?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: His Will, Sir, wherein he makes me his sole Executrix.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Will! why what the Devil does he mean, seriously I can't find it out?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he's gone to fight.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: How fight, Madam! On my Soul then I believe Friendly's Second.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: You're in the right, he is so, and I am lost for ever!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O foolish Friendly, this thy Mistake has made me the most wretched of Woman-kind! Such variety of Thoughts load my afflicted Breast, that I know not what to think: I rave, am mad, not knowing what my Folly may produce; I fear for both, for both my Heart does bleed.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Miserable Maid! nay, miserable Wife! but much more miserable Widow! O my dear Bonvile!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Duce take me, if e're I saw a Company so Phlegmatick in all my Life: Mr. Venter, prethee let's have a Song to pass away the Time, and put Life into the Bride.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Mr. Spruce: Here, who waits?— Servant Enter and Exit. Call in the Musick, and desire 'em to oblige the Ladies with a new Song.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your self, Sir, you mean?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Nay all of us I protest.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Ay, ay, all of us.

div.stage: Enter Musick and others who sing.
A Dialogue set by Seignior Baptist.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A Woman's Love

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: And Man's is such,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Still too little,

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Or else too much.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Men are Extreams,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And Women too,

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: All, all are false,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: All, all like you.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: You'l swear and lie,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If you'l believe,

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: And sigh and die,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yet still deceive.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Your Vows and Oaths,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your Smiles and Tears,

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Are all but Baits,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Are all but Snares.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: To win a Heart,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And then destroy,

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: The easy Fool,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The promis'd Ioy.

p.hi: I'le have you offer no more your Pretending,
Nor will I suffer your modish Dissembling:

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: For Honour commands,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And Freedom withstands,

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: What you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And you.

p.hi: I know wou'd have me be, your Slave,
I know wou'd have me be, your Slave.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I never will agree,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ever will be free.

div.stage: After the Song enter Iustice Merryman, Summerfield, and three or four Sailers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Daughter, Daughter! Where's my Daughter? I say, Where's my Daughter? O Girl, I have the best News to tell you—

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: What of my Husband, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, no, of your Cousin, Girl, of your Cousin.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: What of him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Such a Cousin, Girl, such a dear Cousin he is, as Alexander the Great, if he were alive, might be proud and boast of.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: You're welcome here again, Sir; You've made but a short Voyage, pray what occasion'd your Return so speedily?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Madam, I render you ten thousand Thanks; Your Generosity and Goodness has wholly made me yours; I am the humblest of your faithful Admirers.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Forbear such lavish Gratitude; You'r too profuse in your Acknowledgment of your small Favours. But pray be brief, and let me know the happy Occasion of this your sudden Return, I long methinks to hear it.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Madam, you may command me— Not to molest the Company with the Recital of every vain and needless Circumstance; 'twas briefly thus. Scarce had we passed by Marget on our Course, when on a sudden, from the Top-mast head, a Sailer cries, All hands Aloft, three Sails ahead: With that we rumidg and clear our Deck, our Gun-room arm'd, and all things now are ready for a Fight. The Ships before descried, with warlike Stems cut the resisting Waves, whilst from their Pendants fluttering in the Air, we found they were three Dunkirk Privateers; they having made our English Cross advanced, salute us with a Broad-side, to make us strike and yield: But we, who ne're knew as yet what 'twas so cowardly to yield, and not regarding their unequal Odds, fell boldly on, returning Fire for Fire. The Engagement then grew desperate, for they on either Side fired in amain, whilst we withstood their Force. At length they boldly grappled, and laid us close aboard, and we as bravely beat them off again.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But now, Daughter, mark what follows, for that's worth all, I faith it is; therefore go on, dear Cuz go on.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Sea-room at length we got; when (as Fate wou'd have it) an unlucky Shot struck both the Captain and Lieutenant dead. Then we began to fear, and all our noble Hearts were trembling with despair.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, no, not all Daughter— But you shall hear more— Ods bobs you shall.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: How cou'd it be otherwise, when both our Commanders now were lost? therefore to strike was all the Talk—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, ay, now Daughter, now comes the Play, the other was only the Prologue.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: But Fortune favouring, and the Wind springing a fresh Gale, we got clear off and try'd to make a running Fight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, but Cuz, how did we do all this? by whose Order and Direction?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, 'twas of so small Moment, that already it has slipt my treacherous Memory.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Oh, ho! has it so! Ha, ha, ha! But it has not mine, I thank you, no marry has it not, as you shall hear— Then he, with an undaunted Spirit, started up amongst the Saylers, and—

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Nay pray Sir—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
By the Foot of Pharaoh I'll not be balkt; he, I say, with an Heroick Voice cried out, Courage brave Boys, Charge and Discharge amain; come I'll supply your fall'n Captain's place. At this blest News they all fell on again, with ten thousand times more Fury than before: Victory, Victory, was all their cry, whilst he my
Cousin here, whom I shall ne're forget, for by the Lord, methinks, I see him in the Fight this very Instant, now running this way, now running that way, now down to the Gun-room to encourage those that fought there; now upon the Deck again, still crying out, Fear not, brave Boys, the Day will soon be our's.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: O pray, Sir, let me intreat you to forbear, you make me ashamed, I protest, to hear you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ashamed, say you? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Good Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I will, I will— At length the proud French swallowing too many of our English Balls, two of 'em very fairly cried, Your Servants Gentlemen, farewel, and down they went. The other having lost most of her Men, resolved to leave us; but we being too nimble, overtook her, clapt some Men aboard, and brought her in a Prize: And this my brave Man of War here, was the first that boarded her with Sword in Hand.

sp.speaker: 1 Sailer.
sp.p: Of all this I was an Eye-witness.

sp.speaker: 2 Sailer.
sp.p: And so was I.

sp.speaker: 3 Sailer.
sp.p: And I, and all of us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, and many more stout Boys besides.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Sir, we are all indebted to your Valour; such Voyages as these, from small Venturers, in time may make us great Merchants.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well, never was Fight better managed before, that's certain.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: No, never, never!

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: Better, say you? No nor half so well.

sp.speaker: 3 Sail.
sp.p: If it were in our Power, we'd make him Admiral, so we wou'd.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Gentlemen, 'tis to your Valours all, that I am indebted for the Honour I have gain'd: And that I may not seem wholly ungrateful, there, there's something in token of my Thankfulness. Gives 'em Money.

sp.speaker: 1, 2, 3 Sailers.
sp.p: Heaven bless your Worship.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Come Cousin, we'l withdraw into the Parlour: And if these honest Friends will be pleased to drink what our House affords, they shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: Thank you Mistress with all our Hearts. Exeunt all but Sailers.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: Well, this Mr. Summerfield is a brave Fellow, Gadzooks he is.

sp.speaker: 3 Sail.
sp.p: Ay Tom so he is; had it not been for him, we had all been taken on my Conscience.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: On my Soul and so we had: O if you had but seen him when he boarded the Monsieur, 'twou'd have made you laugh 'till you had split your Sides. He came up to the Captain o'this fashion with a Slap— ha! and gave him such a back-handed wipe, that he cut off his Head as genteely, as tho he had served seven Years Apprenticeship to't.

div.stage: Enter Servant with a Bowl of Punch.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Mr. Summerfield desires ye to be merry, and has sent you this to drink his Health.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: O, the Lord bless him, he's a fine Gentleman, and so pray tell him, and withal give him our hearty Thanks; Dost hear Boy?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: What is't Brother?

sp.speaker: 3 Sail.
sp.p: Punch by this Light!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hoo-ra, Hoo-ra, Viva Mr. Summerfield, Viva, Hoora.

div.stage: [The first Sailer takes the Bowl of Punch, walks in state round the Stage, and sings; the others all follow.]

lg.l: Here's a Health to jolly Bacchus,
Here's a Health to jolly Bacchus,
Hi ho, hi ho, hi ho.
For he will merry make us,
For he will merry make us,
Hi ho, hi ho, hi ho.
Then sit ye down together,
Then sit ye down together.

div.stage: They all sit down with the Bowl in the middle.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: Pshaw! Pox o'th' this old Song, prithee let's have a Dance.

sp.speaker: 3 Sail.
sp.p: With all my Heart; strike up Musick.

div.stage: The Sailers and their Wives dance.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.l: So, well done my Lads, now let's aboard amain,
And suck our Faces o're and o're again.
Brandy we've got enough, by this blest Chance,
We'l nothing drink but Punch, when we get France.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hoora! Hoora! Exeunt omnes.

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

div.head: ACT the Fourth. A Tavern. 2 Tables, three Chairs to each.
div.stage: Enter Compasse, Peg, and Pettifog. A Drawer meets them.

sp.speaker: Drawer,
sp.p: WElcome Gentlemen. Please to walk into a Room?

sp.speaker: Compasse:
sp.p: Aye Boy. Come Mr. Pettifog, please you sit.

sp.speaker: Pettifog:
sp.p: With all my Heart; Come Mistress.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What Wine will you be pleased to drink, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Ask the good Woman: speak Mistress.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Canary for her; I know what relishes her Palat best. A Quart of brisk Canary, Boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Ye shall have the best in England.— Coming, Coming, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: What call you this same Tavern, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: The King's Head, Sir.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: The King's Head: Marry, it has a good Neighbour of Guild-hall. It takes many a fair Pound upon that ' n Account, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: (within) A Quart of Canary in the King's head, score.

div.stage: Enter Drawer, fills a Glass, and gives it Compasse.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, Here's a Glass of the richest Canary that ever came over, the very Quintessence of the Grape I assure you.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Say'st thou so? Why then there's a Tester for thee, and so leave us—. Come, Mr. Pettifog, [Exit Drawer] and 't please you my Service to you. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, Sir.— Mrs. my Service to you, your Husband's good Health. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: With all my Heart indeed, Here my dear black ey'd Rogue, thy n'own good Health. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Thank you Peg, thank you, so now let's mind our Business.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Ventere, his Wife, and Dodge, to another Table in the same Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Show a Room, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Ne're a private Room?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: No Sir, the House is full.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Ods fish, whom have we here, my Wife's Merchant, with his Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Ye know we promised to give him a Meeting here.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: 'Tis true we did so,— but come to the Business in hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Well, bring us a Bottle of your best Red.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: You shall have it, Sir. Exit Drawer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: And what do you think of my Cause, Mr. Dodge?

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: O we shall carry it most certainly: You have Money to go through with the Business; and ne're fear but we'll trounce them swingingly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: I warrant you think it very strange, Mr. Dodge, that I am at this Charge and Expence to bring a farther Charge upon me.

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: Not I, I assure you, Sir, for I know you are a wise Man, and know very well what you do; besides you have Money, Money enough, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ven.
sp.p: Why the short and the long of the Business is this; I made a Purchase lately, and in that I did estate the Child (about which I'm sued) Joint-Purchaser with me in all the Land I bought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: Right Husband; and you know 'twas I that advised you to make the Purchase, and therefore I'll never give my Consent to have the Child brought up by such a stinking Tar-barrel as now sues for him; he'd only bring him up to be a Swabber; no, no, he was born a Merchant and a Gentleman, and he shall live and die so.

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: You are a worthy Gentlewoman upon my word, there are but few of such a noble Temper: But what makes the Fool of the Husband then so troublesome; does he not know when he's well?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ven.
sp.p: So 'tis a sign.

sp.speaker: Dodge.
sp.p: A Blockhead, to proclaim his own Disgrace, and make himself laugh'd at.
